Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Refining and Testing Methods for Identifying and Quantifying Gaseous Oxidized Mercury in Air
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is focused on improving the measurement methods for gaseous oxidized mercury (GOM) in the atmosphere. Development will continue on a simple, calibrated system for passive sampling of GOM followed by thermal desorption. Mass spectrometric analysis will be used to identify specific GOM compounds in the environment. A variety of collection and pre-concentration materials and configurations will be tested. A field-ready calibrator for oxidized mercury compounds will be built that will allow for routine verification of GOM measurements by Tekran and other measurement systems.

Gaseous oxidized mercury compounds are easily converted to methyl mercury, the form of mercury that is of most concern for human and ecosystem health. These compounds are also of concern because they can become efficiently taken up by ecosystems. This project will improve our understanding of the chemistry and fate of mercury in the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although a lot of focus has been placed on climate change science and modeling over the past decade, it is important to recognize that other significant scientific issues exist, and accurate, calibrated scientific observations are needed to verify all models.  This work focused on developing measurement and calibration methods for atmospheric mercury (Hg).  Our laboratory and field work has demonstrated that, contrary to popular opinion, the instrument used in networks worldwide to measure different forms of Hg in the air provides inaccurate measurements of gaseous oxidized and particulate bound mercury. Mercury is a subtle neurotoxin that can contribute to dementia, and affects humans and wildlife. Mercury is emitted into the atmosphere, where it is transported long distances and undergoes chemical transformations and is deposited to ecosystems. There are three forms of atmospheric Hg: Gaseous Elemental (GEM), Gaseous Oxidized (Hg 2+ and Hg1+ forms; GOM), and Particulate Bound (PBM). GEM is the most abundant with concentrations in general ~ 1 ng g-1  in the Southern Hemisphere and ~ 1.5 ng g-1 in the Northern Hemisphere (due to more people and industry), and greater concentrations in naturally enriched and contaminated areas. Our work funded by NSF  has demonstrated that the method currently used to measure gaseous oxidized mercury (GOM) worldwide is biased low by 2-to-13 times, and this form can be up to 25% of the mercury in the planetary boundary air (air near the earth’s surface), and as much as 100% of mercury in the spring in the Artic. This has significant implications for human and wildlife health, since GOM compounds are more water soluble, bioavailable, and more readily converted to methylmercury, the form of mercury that is able to bioaccumulate and biomagnify in aquatic food chains, leading to neurotoxic effects for those who consume high trophic-level fish and food such as rice. Results of this study counter a long held paradigm that GEM is 99% of Hg in the atmosphere.

In addition, these results are important for global policy. The Minamata Convention on Mercury has been signed by 128 nations and is currently being ratified. Its primary objective is to protect human health and the environment from releases of Hg.  The Minamata Convention relied on the best scientific information about atmospheric mercury that was available at the time, but through this NSF project and others, the science of atmospheric mercury is rapidly changing, allowing for better understanding of the sources, transport, and fate of atmospheric mercury.

Modelers typically assume one GOM compound is dominant. Recent work funded through this NSF project has demonstrated that there are a variety of oxidized compounds, and that these vary across time and space. The chemistry of the compounds measured using a simple thermal desorption method that was developed with NSF funding are similar in California, Nevada, and Florida, and at urban and rural locations. For example, results indicate 7 different GOM compounds exist in the Pensacola area, including HgBr2, HgCl2, HgO, Hg-nitrogen and sulfur compounds, and two unknown compounds. These are derived from oxidation of mercury by local pollution and long-range transport from Asia. Because these results are contrary to popular scientific opinion, this work will require a total change for our frame of reference for understanding and measuring atmospheric Hg. 

This project also focused on developing a calibration system for atmospheric Hg analytical systems; and demonstrates why field measurements are necessary for modelers; and why scientists must not forget that observations, replication, calibration, and verification of accuracy of methods are essential.
